intro: Syngonanthus bracteosus, commonly known as the bracteate sedge, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with three-ranked leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, typical of the sedge family. Syngonanthus bracteosus thrives in wet or marshy habitats, often found in swampy areas or along the edges of water bodies. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
